speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: SCENE II. The coast of Wales. A castle in view.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Drums; flourish and colours. Enter KING RICHARD II, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, DUKE OF AUMERLE, and Soldiers

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: After your late tossing on the breaking seas?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To stand upon my kingdom once again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As a long-parted mother with her child

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And do thee favours with my royal hands.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which with usurping steps do trample thee:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Hath power to keep you king in spite of all.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The means that heaven yields must be embraced,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And not neglected; else, if heaven would,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The proffer'd means of succor and redress.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss;

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Grows strong and great in substance and in power.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That when the searching eye of heaven is hid,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Behind the globe, that lights the lower world,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In murders and in outrage, boldly here;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But when from under this terrestrial ball

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And darts his light through every guilty hole,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then murders, treasons and detested sins,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Who all this while hath revell'd in the night

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall see us rising in our throne, the east,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His treasons will sit blushing in his face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Not able to endure the sight of day,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Not all the water in the rough rude sea

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The breath of worldly men cannot depose

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The deputy elected by the Lord:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A glorious angel: then, if angels fight,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Weak men must fall, for heaven still guards the right.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter EARL OF SALISBURY

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Welcome, my lord how far off lies your power?

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: And bids me speak of nothing but despair.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: One day too late, I fear me, noble lord,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: O, call back yesterday, bid time return,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But now the blood of twenty thousand men

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, till so much blood thither come again,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have I not reason to look pale and dead?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All souls that will be safe fly from my side,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For time hath set a blot upon my pride.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I had forgot myself; am I not king?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: At thy great glory. Look not to the ground,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ye favourites of a king: are we not high?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: More health and happiness betide my liege

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And what loss is it to be rid of care?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Greater he shall not be; if he serve God,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They break their faith to God as well as us:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The worst is death, and death will have his day.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: To bear the tidings of calamity.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Like an unseasonable stormy day,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: As if the world were all dissolved to tears,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: So high above his limits swells the rage

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Strive to speak big and clap their female joints

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Of double-fatal yew against thy state;

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Against thy seat: both young and old rebel,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all goes worse than I have power to tell.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What is become of Bushy? where is Green?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That they have let the dangerous enemy

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would they make peace? terrible hell make war

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Upon their spotted souls for this offence!

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Sweet love, I see, changing his property,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Ay, all of them at Bristol lost their heads.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Where is the duke my father with his power?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No matter where; of comfort no man speak:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's choose executors and talk of wills:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet not so, for what can we bequeath

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Save our deposed bodies to the ground?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And nothing can we call our own but death

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And that small model of the barren earth

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And tell sad stories of the death of kings;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How some have been deposed; some slain in war,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All murder'd: for within the hollow crown

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That rounds the mortal temples of a king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Scoffing his state and grinning at his pomp,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Allowing him a breath, a little scene,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Infusing him with self and vain conceit,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As if this flesh which walls about our life,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were brass impregnable, and humour'd thus

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Comes at the last and with a little pin

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bores through his castle wall, and farewell king!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With solemn reverence: throw away respect,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tradition, form and ceremonious duty,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For you have but mistook me all this while:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I live with bread like you, feel want,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Taste grief, need friends: subjected thus,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How can you say to me, I am a king?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: But presently prevent the ways to wail.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And so your follies fight against yourself.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And fight and die is death destroying death;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My father hath a power; inquire of him

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And learn to make a body of a limb.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To change blows with thee for our day of doom.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This ague fit of fear is over-blown;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: An easy task it is to win our own.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Men judge by the complexion of the sky

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: The state and inclination of the day:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: So may you by my dull and heavy eye,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: I play the torturer, by small and small

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all your northern castles yielded up,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all your southern gentlemen in arms

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Upon his party.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou hast said enough.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of that sweet way I was in to despair!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What say you now? what comfort have we now?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That bids me be of comfort any more.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That power I have, discharge; and let them go

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For I have none: let no man speak again

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To alter this, for counsel is but vain.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My liege, one word.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He does me double wrong

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Discharge my followers: let them hence away,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt
